comments:
This course covers Sturm-Liouville problems, orthogonal functions, Fourier
series, and partial differential equations including solutions of the wave, heat and Laplace
equations, Fourier transforms. There is also an introduction to complex analysis.
Students felt that this was a “great class” and reported gaining a lot of insight and
knowledge from the course. The great majority of students found the material covered
“interesting” and “informative.”
Many felt that Professor Shatz was both “a great lecturer” and “a brilliant and
talented man.” Most students felt that he excelled in communicating complex material
students in a manner that was easily understandable. However, a few students cautioned
that he is “not very nice” and that one should be “prepared to be made fun of by the
professor at some point in the course.”
Students found his exams to be difficult, but not unreasonable. One student,
however, did point out that although the exams were difficult, all the material had been
thoroughly covered in lecture.

This course looks at the Sturm-Liouville problems, orthogonal functions, Fourier
series, and partial differential equations including solutions of the wave, heat and Laplace
equations, Fourier transforms. In addition, it offers an introduction to complex analysis. It
uses symbolic manipulation and graphics software.
Students found that the course starts off relatively easy with complex analysis and
gets progressively much harder going to Fourier series and PDE's. The rate at which the
difficulty increases is almost shocking. Professor Lu communicates the material fine, but
the order in which he works on the blackboard is usually difficult to follow. The exam
format is good with both multiple choice and open-ended problems. However, the
multiple-choice questions are far more difficult than the open-ended questions or
homework problems.
Many students said that Professor Lu seemed more interested in getting through
the material than in actually having his students understand it. His lectures were nicely
structured and he was good at describing his thought process and what steps he was
doing. However, he only went through proofs in his lectures and never did examples; the
proofs being completely unnecessary for completing the homework and test problems. He
was reluctant to answer questions and do examples in class, rendering the lecture
completely useless if you didn't understand what he was teaching, which the majority of
the class didn't. One student said, “Without the TAs, this class would have been
impossible.”
The prerequisite for this course is MATH 240. Students said that the tests were
based on the homework and were very fair with few surprises. Cramming before each
exam can yield a decent grade, but the material is never really learned well enough for
any sort of application other than the tests.
